Campaign Overview.name: Campaign Overview
Campaign Overview.text:
Campaign Overview

Runelord Xanderghul's rule over the nation of Xin-Cyrusian lasted from the dawn of Thassilon to its fall. He was the first runelord to attain mythic power, a source he used to secretly establish himself as the force behind one of Thassilon's most widespread and mysterious religions—the Cult of the Peacock Spirit. Yet for all his power, not even Xanderghul could withstand Earthfall, and when fire came from the skies, he was forced to retreat into stasis within an extraplanar shelter hidden within his own runewell, a domain known as the Eye of Arrogance.

For thousands of years, the runelords remained in stasis. Though Earthfall's devastation was not quite powerful enough to reach them in their metaphysical safe rooms, it proved more than enough to lock them away, turning their fortresses into tombs. They would have remained forever locked away had chance and design not seen one of them, Runelord Karzoug, slowly awaken. His return to power brought the legacies and legends of Thassilon out of obscurity and into the modern world, and though he was defeated, it wasn't much longer before the other runelords rose as well.

Of this second wave, Runelord Alaznist was the next to wake, and she moved quickly against Runelord Xanderghul, knowing full well that once he emerged from his torpor, she would be unable to stand against him. She broke into his domain to murder Xanderghul even as he woke. Xanderghul's soul slipped from his body, but death was not a finality for one as powerful as he. Rather than enter the River of Souls, Xanderghul was reborn in the body of an illusory duplicate hidden deep within his first fortress, the Temple of the Peacock Spirit.

Still, this was a significant blow to Xanderghul's plans and pride, and in the end, it left him in a much-weakened state. When a group of heroes who had gathered to oppose Alaznist's return came upon the Temple of the Peacock Spirit, Xanderghul suffered the indignity of death at the hands of inferiors for a second time. This time, however, no magic remained to save him. This time, his soul had no choice—it entered the River of Souls and sped on its way to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.QZD0u1jxwz0kj8uI]{Pharasma's} Boneyard to be judged.

Or it would have, had Xanderghul's soul not been a rare prize long sought after by powerful forces from other realities. A powerful astradaemon known as the High Justice captured Xanderghul's soul, and when the same heroes who'd previously defeated Xanderghul later confronted the High Justice, the astradaemon sacrificed Xanderghul's soul in a bid to use its energies to save himself from destruction. Consigned to the depths of the eclipse that broods over Abaddon, Xanderghul's story would have finally ended there, digested over the course of eternity in the metaphysical belly of one of the eldest entities of this cycle of reality.

But then the Godsrain changed everything.

Xanderghul's Escape.name: Xanderghul's Escape
Xanderghul's Escape.text:
Xanderghul's Escape

Earning a Destiny

If your PCs are already 12th-level characters, perhaps after playing through an Adventure Path like Seven Dooms for Sandpoint, which ends at that level, then you're ready to play this adventure's introduction, “Dreams of Destiny.” If, on the other hand, your group is still 11th-level or lower, as they might be after playing something like the Myth-Speaker Adventure Path, you'll need to decide how the party levels up to be ready for Revenge of the Runelords.

Swift Leveling in a Dream: The quickest method is to run the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01dreamsofdest00]{Dreams of Destiny} encounter for the PCs at their current level; if you do so, remember to adjust the DCs during the Apocalyptic Visions section to make them appropriate for their lower levels, as suggested on the DCs by Level table in GM Core page 53. These DCs should be hard, very hard, or incredibly hard—if your group is 11th-level, for example, you'll simply reduce each of the DCs as listed in the encounter by 2. Once the PCs complete the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01apocalypticv00]{Apocalyptic Visions} encounter, regardless of whether they succeed or fail, the visions automatically level them up to 12th level. Play proceeds normally from there.

When @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.51kMMWaT6CqpGlGk]{Achaekek} assassinated @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.88vRw2ZVPax4hhga]{Gorum}, the war god's body erupted, and fragments of him known as warshards spread out across the Great Beyond during an event now known as Godsrain. One warshard hurtled into Abaddon then plunged through the eclipse above Abaddon itself. As it did, Xanderghul's soul grasped it like a drowning man thrown a lifeline. The warshard continued its metaphysical journey with what remained of Xanderghul's soul and a not insignificant amount of Abaddon's cosmic power attached to it. This warshard would have likely hurtled through the multiverse forever if not for the interference of an ancient atrocity known as the Ashen Man, who'd long been waiting for just such a moment. Seeing an opportunity to quicken Golarion's destruction after having been denied the pleasure of witnessing its end before, the Ashen Man stepped in to guide the flight of the Xanderghul-infused warshard so that its route was anything but random.

On Golarion, rising tensions between Runelord Belimarius and Queen Sorshen, as well as growing discontent among the leaders of the southern Linnorm Kingdoms, were cast into high gear as the influence of the Godsrain washed over the Saga Lands. Many scrambled for warshards where they fell, but one caught the eye of many as it scythed across the night sky. Unlike the other warshards, this one looked like a brightly shining falling star that left three brilliant trails in its wake—one blood red (and infused with Gorum's legacy), one jet black (and infused with the raw digestive nihilism of Abaddon's eclipse), and the largest—an iridescent display that, unbeknownst to all observers, was Xanderghul's soul itself. Dubbed the Trinity Star, agents from both halves of New Thassilon, the Linnorm Kingdoms, and more scrambled into the north central Kodar Mountains where the star fell in hopes of recovering it. Yet no sign of it remained—not even an impact crater. Under the Ashen Man's manipulations, the Trinity Star pierced through the heart of Xanderghul's runewell, where he was reborn within the Eye of Arrogance. There, Xanderghul's soul became a ghost, where he remained disoriented and trapped for a time.

The Ashen Man's next step was to use one of the many agents he'd been influencing toward pursuing apocalyptic goals. The most well-suited for the particular task he had in mind was an up-and-coming Thassilonian wizard named Aethusa, whom the Ashen Man goaded into seeking out Xanderghul's runewell in search of greater power. There, Aethusa became possessed by Xanderghul's ghost, allowing the reborn runelord to escape and start plotting his ascension into divinity.

No longer is Xanderghul content to rule a nation. He has within him the blood of a dead god, visions from the heart of Abaddon, and a mysterious partner in the Ashen Man. Xanderghul's plan is to ascend into the role of a new god by using the Saga Lands as payment for his ascension. Thereafter, his goal is to take revenge against a world that has denied him so many times and wreak a devastation across Golarion that no simple mortal could dare to dream of.

–5300 Liralarue's study reaches a point where she considers her work to be the foundation of an eighth school of Thassilonian magic—one focused on predictive magic and arising from the sin of vainglory.

The planetary conjunction Ramlock's ancient magics predicted occurs, but heroes prevent the doomsday these devices would have triggered, much to the Ashen Man's frustration. He then turns his attention northward to the next significant threat facing Golarion—the apocalypse seed in the Saga Lands.

In doing so, she attracts the Ashen Man's attention, who approaches her as a mysterious benefactor. She believes him to be the guiding spirit of her past runelord lives.

Campaign Summary.name: Campaign Summary
Campaign Summary.text:
Campaign Summary

Lord of the Trinity Star

By Michelle Y. Kim

Pathfinder Adventure Path #219, Levels 12–14

The PCs arrive in the city of Xin-Eurythnia (once known as Xin-Shalast), to which they've come in hopes of celebrating the creation of an immense portal that will allow the city to trade with the rest of the world. When disaster strikes, the PCs must lead Xin-Eurythnia's survivors on an exodus down the mountains to safety in the lowlands. The PCs later learn that a group known as the Risen of the Trinity Star was responsible for the earthquake and track the cult down to the southeastern Linnorm Kingdoms. There, they learn that its leader is the reborn Runelord Xanderghul, who seeks vengeance on all the Saga Lands!

Crypt of Runes

By Bill Fischer

Pathfinder Adventure Path #220, Levels 15–17

New Thassilon erupts into war as Runelord Belimarius takes advantage of the fact that Sorshen is missing to begin claiming the nation for herself. As the PCs now know, however, Runelord Xanderghul's cult is the true threat. The PCs travel to the risen isle of Xin to learn how to reach the cult's new headquarters, which are hidden in the sprawling vastness of the Emerald Chambers. After exploring the legendary Crypt of Runes, they shatter the cult, but it may be too late, for several risen runelords allied with the cult are in the process of opening Doomsday Doors across the Saga Lands. The PCs must lead mass retaliations against the apocalyptic events these doors threaten to unleash, after which they must enter the Dreamlands. Once there, they must deny Xanderghul his means to immortality and rescue Liralarue from a prison in Leng.

Into the Apocalypse Archive

By Jessica Redekop

Pathfinder Adventure Path #221, Levels 18–20

The PCs confront and defeat Runelord Belimarius after she invades the ruins of Xin-Eurythnia, but then must turn their attention to Jandelay, the Apocalypse Archive, where Xanderghul waits. By traveling to Spindlehorn, the PCs conjure the Oliphaunt and “ride” the legendary monster back into Jandelay. Once in that remote plane, they must seek out Xanderghul and defeat him before he can perform a ritual at the plane's heart that will bring about the end of Golarion, add the ruined world to Jandelay as a trophy, and catapult him into power as the god of an unsuspecting new world.

Adventure Summary.name: Adventure Summary
Adventure Summary.text:
Lord of the Trinity Star

A Mythic Campaign

Revenge of the Runelords is designed for mythic PCs built using the rules for mythic callings and destinies as presented in Pathfinder War of Immortals. As with all rules for Pathfinder, these can also be found for free online, but some groups may wish to play this campaign using standard PCs rather than mythic ones. In such a case, the GM should adjust the adventure. This will require some work, especially when it comes to replacing mythic abilities for creatures, treasures, and other rewards—in most cases, you can simply remove these abilities and activations, but in others, you'll want to design similar, less powerful variants to take their place. Also, keep in mind that mythic adventures skew more difficult—you'll want to adjust most of the encounters in this campaign down by one threat level, which may involve rebuilding creature stat blocks or replacing groups of monsters with slightly less powerful variants.

Chapter 1: The Rising Star

After a strange dream in which their mythic destinies first manifest, the PCs awaken in the city of Xin-Eurythnia, where they've been invited to attend the unveiling of a portal that will link the city to distant Absalom. Yet sabotage lurks in the shadows, and the PCs soon learn of a terrifying new threat to the region—a cult known as the Risen of the Trinity Star, which appears to include resurrected runelords among its members!

Chapter 2: Flight of the Eurythnians

After a cataclysmic disaster that began with Queen Sorshen's vanishing and got worse from there, the city of Xin-Eurythnia must be evacuated! The PCs do their best to gather the people, recruit their leaders, and prepare for an arduous journey south to safety. But supernatural opposition and more agents of the Risen of the Trinity Star are eager to make the trek anything but safe!

Chapter 3: Secrets of Pride

With the aid of a dragon, the PCs discover that the Risen have ties to the lost city of Xin-Cyrusian. They travel west, only to discover that the ruins have been abandoned by the cultists. Still, there's much to learn from what they left behind, including a shocking revelation—Runelord Xanderghul, the most dangerous runelord of all, has risen from the dead and returned to Golarion in pursuit of revenge!

Advancement Track

“Lord of the Trinity Star” is designed for four mythic characters.

12The PCs begin this adventure at 12th level.

13The PCs should be 13th level when Chapter 2 begins.

14The PCs should be 14th level before they travel to Xin-Cyrusian.

The PCs should reach 15th level by the time they complete the adventure.

The Rising Star.name: The Rising Star
The Rising Star.text:
Chapter 1: The Rising Star

When @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.88vRw2ZVPax4hhga]{Gorum}, the god of war, was slain by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.51kMMWaT6CqpGlGk]{Achaekek}, the god of assassins, reverberations spread through all worlds on which the Lord in Iron was worshipped. The Godsrain filled the skies, and pieces of Gorum's body hurtled down to scatter fragments that would become known, in time, as warshards. These fragments contained great power—each was unique, yet the magic found within was potent indeed. Mortals scrambled to recover these warshards in the days, months, and years to follow the Godsrain.

Yet not all of what fell from the skies during the Godsrain proved so easy to track down and claim. In the skies above the Kodar mountains, many beheld the sight of a falling star with three tails: one red, one black, and one a spectacle of iridescent energy. Witnesses watched as this so-called Trinity Star crashed somewhere within the western heights of the range, and a race was on to recover this unusual warshard. Yet though many tried, none could find its landing site, or even a crater to mark its arrival. It wasn't long before troll warbands, agents of the disgraced (and presumed dead) Linnorm King Opir Eightfingers, competing mercenaries in service to Runelord Belimarius and Queen Sorshen, and a not-inconsiderable number of adventurers fell to frustrations, slowly shifting their hunt for the fallen star to violence toward each other. Some of these groups were slaughtered, and others soon abandoned the hunt for warshards elsewhere in the world. A few even began to think of the Trinity Star as some form of mass hallucination and regarded those who remained focused on it as hopeless obsessives.

Much has happened since the Trinity Star fell to turn minds away from its visitation, yet soon, all will learn the truth. For it did indeed fall into the Kodar Mountains, and with it came the soul of Thassilon's most notorious villain—Runelord Xanderghul.

Mythic Points

Opportunities for PCs to regain Mythic Points by completing mythic deeds or defeating mythic foes appear in this adventure, but these shouldn't be the only way to regain Mythic Points. Remember that a PC should regain a Mythic Point whenever they follow their calling and when a PC achieves a legendary accomplishment. You should keep an eye on opportunities to award PCs these points—in certain encounters in this adventure, suggestions for when to award points for legendary accomplishments are given, but don't feel limited to these opportunities. Mythic Points fuel a mythic character's story, and they shouldn't feel constantly starved for them or afraid to use them out of fear of not being able to earn more! Critical successes on rolls can be a great opportunity to award a Mythic Point for a legendary accomplishment, especially if the timing of that critical success is particularly cinematic or thematic for the PC in question. If the PCs don't feel like they're being punished for using these points while simultaneously not spending them frivolously, the rate of Mythic Point renewal is about right!

The tale of Xanderghul's return is presented earlier in this book, @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21900frontm.JournalEntryPage.00campaignover00]{Here}. In the year since his return to Golarion, the runelord has been busy. He spent his first month recovering from his ordeal, hidden away within the demiplane known as the Eye of Arrogance within his Runewell of Pride. When an ill-fated woman seeking Xanderghul's legacy arrived in the ruins of Xin-Cyrusian, Xanderghul swiftly possessed her through her dreams on the first night she slept therein. Now in control of a physical body, Xanderghul set into motion his devastating plans for vengeance against a world that stood in the way of his power one too many times, starting with the perfection of a ritual meant to draw upon the legacies of previous runelords to manifest living incarnations of the long-dead wizards to serve him. By the time this campaign begins, a new secret society—the Risen of the Trinity Star—has come to power in the shadows of the Saga Lands. Most of these cultists have moved on to a new location known as the Emerald Chambers (where Xanderghul had better access to the materials he needed to create even more risen runelords), but some remained behind in Xin-Cyrusian.

While Queen Sorshen and Runelord Belimarius both took note of the fall of the Trinity Star, neither suspect the truth of the matter, and both have had their hands full over the past few years—Runelord Belimarius with orchestrating a slowly growing encroachment into the lands surrounding eastern Thassilon that could boil over into outright invasions of the Lands of the Linnorm Kings and Varisia at a moment's notice, and Queen Sorshen with the final phases of transitioning Karzoug's old capital city of Xin-Shalast into a new trade hub for New Thassilon, now to be known as Xin-Eurythnia.

Xin-Eurythnia's remote location within one of Golarion's most unforgiving mountain ranges was once a key factor in its defense, but today it's proven a significant hindrance to Queen Sorshen in her attempts to establish herself and her nation on the political stage of the Inner Sea. Her most recent efforts to address this issue are on the cusp of realization—an immense portal called the Circle of Open Hands. Once activated, this portal will magically link the city to a similar portal in the city of Absalom, providing a swift and efficient avenue for trade and travel. Alongside the announcement of a grand ceremony to unveil said portal, several invitations were sent to prominent heroes and adventurers throughout all Golarion, inviting them to witness the start of a new chapter of New Thassilon. Many chose to ignore the invitations, either out of suspicion of Sorshen's true intentions or out of practicality once the logistics of traveling to the remote city were considered, but those who accepted and made the journey were given a warm reception upon arrival, as well as brand new @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.TkSY6tUfnsgd8xC7]{Sihedron Medallions} to signify their status as honored guests. Complimentary stays at the finest inns have been provided, as well as free meals at taverns and restaurants. The PCs are already great heroes and treated as such by the excited citizens of Xin-Eurythnia, who have no idea of the great heights the PCs are soon to reach.

Forge.text:
B5. Forge Moderate 12

A pair of towering blast furnaces sits against the southern wall of this chamber, while an immense slag pot hangs twenty feet in the air from a set of chains attached to runners along the ceiling. Nearby the wall of hardened lava that partially buried this room, a second slag pot lies in fragments on the floor, surrounded by coils of chain. A door remains to the west, while to the north what was once a doorway is partially blocked by the old lava flow.

A creature moving between area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{B4} and B5 must scramble over the hardened lava that partially blocks the opening in the wall, treating these squares as difficult terrain.

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.wrl83nPWvtHNaCSb]{Haunted Forge}

B5. Forge Moderate 12

@UUID[Actor.7FUYjo2u3PwNVgQi]{Haunted Forge}

Hazard: When the lava flooded the building during Earthfall, several obsessive artisans believed they could outlast the disaster and stubbornly remained within this chamber, losing their lives. The agony and trauma of their demise linger in this room as a deadly haunt, even though their remains are long gone. The greedspawn and Trinity initiates have had a few run-ins with this haunt and know to stick near the northern or western walls whenever they pass through the room, but if the PCs trigger the haunt, the noise it creates is more than enough to draw any surviving creatures from areas @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01materialswar00]{B3} or @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{B4} to the entrances to this room to watch the PCs deal with the haunt and, perhaps, take advantage of the distraction to attack.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.fujIOLioQKM1L7FJ]{Pot}
The dangling slag pot could once be moved around the room or raised and lowered, but those mechanisms have long since seized up, so anyone who wishes to search inside must fly up or otherwise devise a way to get the twenty feet up in the air to peer within the pot. A mass of dawnsilver sits within ancient chunks of slag in the suspended pot; this mass is the equivalent of a dawnsilver ingot.

Trapped Landing.name: Trapped Landing
Trapped Landing.text:
B6. Trapped Landing Moderate 12

Ancient lava flows have buried this balcony walkway to the north and south. To the west, a curved viewing platform looks out over the larger workshop, while to the east stands a large wooden door.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RkW4ULLh8cjcRG33.PlaylistSound.MpaOOFPdr3r6Ytvv]{Endless Realities}

B6. Trapped Landing Moderate 12

@UUID[Actor.AwMqRtAG5AIzUWyX]{Endless Realities}

Hazard: Risen Runelord Gimmel was provided with potent supplies from Xanderghul before he made his trek east to Xin-Eurythnia. He used some of these to create a particularly devious trap here, intended to ensure his privacy while he awaits the moment when the runelord of pride launches his attack on the city. This trap doesn't trigger for those who view Xanderghul as their superior or god (including any cultists of the Peacock Spirit, such as the initiates in area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01workshopunde00]{B4}) but could strand anyone else who approaches in a dizzying forever of falsehood and lies.

Reward: Overcoming this trap is a mythic deed; doing so restores 3 Mythic Points to each PC.

Office.name: Office
Office.text:
B7. Office Severe 12

This large chamber appears to be an office. Four tables sit in the room, their tops cluttered with scrolls, star charts, maps, books, and incense burners spewing a strange, spicy scented smoke into the air. Stone shelves to the east and west stand empty, while glowing stones in the ceiling fill the room with illumination.

Creatures: The creatures who occupy this room are the only actual members of the Risen of the Trinity Star—they hope that, once Xanderghul completes his work, they'll be called upon to help transform Xin-Eurythnia into a new stronghold for their society. These creatures consist of risen Runelord Gimmel, his lamia matriarch associate Vesinra, and three greedspawn soldiers.

Risen Runelord Gimmel commands the most presence, though, even being smaller and less monstrous in shape than his bestial allies. Imperious and with mismatched eyes (one green and human, the other amber and slit like that of a snake), he wears striking green and gold robes and wields a flaming glaive. A PC who sees him can attempt to Recall Knowledge with a @Check[arcana|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or a @Check[society|dc:27|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check. On a success, they recognize his gear and stature as that of a runelord of greed, while on a critical success they realize the man who stands before them is none other than the third runelord of greed, Runelord Gimmel, once again alive and in the flesh!

B7. Office Severe 12

@UUID[Actor.M12ytARCX85Y4vVT]{Risen Runelord Gimmel} @UUID[Actor.Z3tnnsMTMxFHRLJw]{Vesinra} @UUID[Actor.8X6Q6uWj1PXfvLqL]{Greedspawn Soldiers (3)}

The four Risen waste little time speaking with the PCs, although Runelord Gimmel does appear to be exasperated that the party managed to reach them. Vesinra, on the other hand, is eager for the chance to fight, having been “cooped up” in this workshop for too long. She starts combat by casting haste on herself, then slithers forth to engage in melee against the PCs. While hasted, uses her additional action to maneuver into a position where she can target as many enemies as she can with Falchion Swipe. She resorts to her spells again only against foes who manage to stay out of reach or who get past her to attack Runelord Gimmel. She fights until she's reduced to 40 or fewer Hit Points, at which point her loyalty to Gimmel cracks and she flees by casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8]{Translocate} to reappear elsewhere in the city a mile away—she's long lived in the area, knows her way around the underground well, and is unlikely to return to vex the PCs if she flees. The greedspawn soldiers are ferociously loyal to Gimmel, and fight to the death.

Gimmel stays back when the fighting starts, using his spells at range against the party while the others in the room engage in melee. He casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.kOa055FIrO9Smnya]{Wall of Stone} on the first round of combat to try to seal some of the PCs away so that he and his allies can face fewer foes, then moves on to casting his single-target higher-rank spells against the foes he suspects will have the hardest time resisting. He uses Quickened Casting to get spells out more quickly after the first-round tactic of wall of stone (which takes all three of his actions) and uses his mythic power to recharge Quickened Casting twice during the fight, saving one mythic point to potentially remove a condition.

As a legacy from his time as a runelord of greed, risen Runelord Gimmel has prepared greed-themed spells. If reduced to fewer than 40 Hit Points, he attempts to flee, casting a spell to gain enhanced speed (such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.A2JfEKe6BZcTG1S8]{Fly}) to aid his escape. If he does escape, risen Runelord Gimmel should appear again later in the adventure, popping up to attack the PCs again at a particularly dramatic point of your choosing—he has no future role planned for this Adventure Path, so you can use him as you wish in the role of a recurring villain.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.vSwgcBNsdEE4EzhD]{Ceiling} @UUID[Actor.DB9CqDN5QJKqYcN5]{Tabletops}
A total of six everlight crystals are affixed to positions in the ceiling. A PC who spends 10 minutes Searching the documents, tools, and clutter on the tabletops discovers that they mostly concern information and intelligence about Xin-Eurythnia (although the documents stubbornly refer to the city as its outdated name of Xin-Shalast)—a PC who references this collection for an hour gains a +2 item bonus on checks made to Recall Knowledge about the city. More disturbing, these notes are obviously gathered and annotated in a way that plans out several dozen potential methods for a group called the Risen of the Trinity Star to take control of the city once the Unveiling Ceremony is completed. It should be obvious this group wants to secure control of the city and its powerful portal, and it mentions that this small group the PCs just defeated planned on seizing control of the Circle of Open Hands once it was activated. While the cultists the PCs defeated were powerful, it should be apparent that this group would not have been enough to wrest control of a portal defended by Queen Sorshen and her allies. While the notes make no indication of other resources and allies that would aid in this theoretical attack, the implication remains that something dire is afoot. The collection of notes is worth 650 gp for their value as research material alone but is worth much more if the PCs turn them over to Queen Sorshen.

While risen Runelord Gimmel's polearm and non-magical robes fade when he perishes, the one “real” item he carried does not—it clatters to the ground upon his death. This is a slate of distant letters, on which he's scribbled a note: “As feared, our city is crawling with heroes. One group is getting close to us. If you don't hear back soon, assume the worst.” The message is “signed” with one final word—the rune of greed. If the PCs activate the slate to send a message to whomever holds the other, the only message they receive is something akin to, “Your desperate scramble will be for naught. The Risen will have our revenge, and the Lord of the Trinity Star shall rise above us all.” After this, no further reply will ever come. (The other slate of distant letters is held by risen Runelord Karzoug, whom the PCs will face in the next adventure.)

Event 1: Enjoying the Festivities.name: Event 1: Enjoying the Festivities
Event 1: Enjoying the Festivities.text:
Event 1. Enjoying the Festivities

This event repeats four times during the day, once at the start of the day and then again between each event leading up to @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01event4uninvi00]{Event 4}. When this event takes place, each PC must decide upon one of the following pursuits during the festival. Since a few hours pass during each of these, the PCs can cast spells or pursue other Exploration activities as they see fit, such as if they need to heal or otherwise recover from an event.

Bargain Hunt: The PC goes shopping, hoping to find something they've been wanting to buy. The player works with the GM to select a common alchemical or magical item of 15th or lower level, then attempts a Society check against the standard DC for that level (GM Core 53). On a success, the PC finds that item for sale at 90% its normal price. On a critical success, the PC finds that item for sale at 75% of its normal price.

Mythic Guardian: The PC can keep an eye out for trouble, drawing upon their mythic destiny. If the next event is @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01event2constr00]{Event 2}, the PC rolls their first check to overcome an obstacle at mythic proficiency. If the next event is @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01event3thesis00]{Event 3}, their first check to Debate is rolled at mythic proficiency. If the next event is @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01event4uninvi00]{Event 4}, the PC's first check to disable the hazard encountered there is rolled at mythic proficiency. If the next event is @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01event5devast00]{Event 5}, the PC rolls for initiative using mythic proficiency.

Perform for the Crowd: The PC can attempt to earn income by dancing, singing, or otherwise entertaining the crowd. The PC attempts to Earn Income using Performance, selecting any task level up to level 15—the festive nature of the event allows the PC to accomplish a full day's job in the few hours that pass during this event.

Relax: The PC simply enjoys the festival by attempting a @Check[will|dc:30] save. On a success, they feel invigorated, and gain a +1 circumstance bonus to all skill checks made in the following event (@UUID[Item.GsLjm1LBB4rTr6HR]{Festival Vigor}).

Event 2: Constructs Amuck.name: Event 2: Constructs Amuck
Event 2: Constructs Amuck.text:
Event 2. Constructs Amuck

A merchant's product display of constructs has gone haywire, running around the plaza attempting to “serve” the citizens they run into. The PCs must address the issues the constructs have entangled themselves in and ferry them back to their owner for repair before it's time for him to present them to potential customers.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.TozBbePQafB4l9XV]{Constructs Amuck}

This encounter uses the Chase subsystem rules ( GM Core 192). This is a “beat the clock” style chase, where the PCs must accomplish all of the chase obstacles before time runs out in 6 rounds.

Missing Cat Obstacle

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[athletics|dc:30] to climb the tree and retrieve the cat, @Check[nature|dc:32] to lure the cat down, @Check[deception|dc:35] to swiftly disguise the construct as something less frightening.

A construct is attempting to rescue a cat in a tree on behalf of some children, but the terrified cat refuses to come near the construct.

Goblins Love ‘Em Obstacle

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[intimidation|dc:30] to frighten the goblins off, @Check[thievery|dc:32] to temporarily disable the construct so the goblins lose interest, @Check[diplomacy|dc:35] to convince the goblins to give up their “claim”.

One of the constructs has been claimed by a troupe of goblins, who are now using it as part of their act and are loathe to part with it.

Stuck in a Hole Obstacle

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[thievery|dc:30] to disable the thrashing construct temporarily so it can be extracted from the hole with ease, @Check[crafting|dc:32] to quickly loosen the stuck limb so that the construct can get free, @Check[athletics|dc:35] to wrench the construct out of the hole.

A particularly awkward construct has become stuck in a hole in the street and is flailing its limbs about in a haphazard manner.

Powered Down Obstacle

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[arcana|dc:30] to power up the construct, @Check[diplomacy|dc:32] to convince the nearby cart owners to let you use the carts to haul the construct back to the merchant, @Check[athletics|dc:35] to haul the de-powered construct back to the merchant using your own might.

A construct has run out of power and sits motionless by a pile of carts.

Traffic Jam Obstacle

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[diplomacy|dc:30] to direct the crowd to move around the construct, @Check[deception|dc:32] to trick the construct into wanting to follow the PCs rather than remain at the crossroads, @Check[intimidation|dc:35] to frighten the crowds away.

A construct has gotten distracted at a crossroads and is now blithely causing a traffic jam.

Guard Duty Obstacle

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[deception|dc:30] to trick the construct into wanting to follow the PCs instead, @Check[diplomacy|dc:32] to convince the noble that the construct isn't theirs, @Check[society|dc:35] to use the noble's status in the city against them.

One of the constructs has been mistaken for part of a noble's retinue of their own constructs and is following them dutifully.

Rewards: @UUID[Actor.Nuqn9vb5fMMQgNL7]{Merchant's Single Reward} @UUID[Actor.lqCwcvrghH3UvEKQ]{Merchant's Additional Reward}
Each obstacle completed represents one missing construct returned to the merchant, who rewards the PCs with 100 gp for each success. The PCs also earn 10 XP for each overcome obstacle, for a total of 60 XP if they recovered them all.

If the PCs overcome all six obstacles in time, the merchant is so impressed that he also gives the party two vials of oil of repulsion in addition to the 600 gp for returning all six. In addition, each PC earns 1 Mythic Point for this legendary accomplishment.

Event 3: Thesis Argument.name: Event 3: Thesis Argument
Event 3: Thesis Argument.text:
Event 3. Thesis Argument

Two wizardly students, who are arguing over which kind of magic is more efficient at the creation of summoning rune hazards, start an illegal duel in the middle of the street. One of the two is Kespern Dantch (studious male human wizard 10), a student of the Runelord's Academy who argues that summoning runes are best crafted via arcane magic, while the other is Cilamali (artistic female gnome druid 10), a visitor from the Linnorm Kingdoms who argues that primal magic offers the superior foundation for these traps. If the PCs don't intervene, the two soon start slinging spells and end up causing a fair amount of collateral damage before they're hauled away by the guards.

Kespern and Cilamali both start with 5 Debate Points (DP). The party has 5 rounds to reduce both of the wizards to 0 DP, with each PC attempting the Debate the Spellcasters activity below.

Debate the Spellcasters

The PC chooses Kespern or Cilamali as their target to debate, and then attempts a skill check to reduce that target's current DP total by arguing against their stance. Against either wizard, a PC can attempt a @Check[intimidation|dc:32] check or a @Check[deception|dc:35] or @Check[diplomacy|dc:35] check. Against Kespern, a PC can attempt a @Check[nature|dc:30] check to argue against his thesis, while against Cilamali, a PC can attempt a @Check[arcana|dc:30] check to do the same. Once one spellcaster is reduced to 0 DP, the PCs gain momentum; reduce all DCs for this activity by 2 as long as one spellcaster is at 0 DP.

Critical Success Both spellcasters are impressed. The target spellcaster loses 2 DP, while the other loses 1 DP.

Success The target spellcaster loses 1 DP.

Failure No DP are lost or gained.

Critical Failure The target spellcaster's argument gains momentum, and they earn 1 DP.

Treasures: @UUID[Actor.OBe0Y7vMpqxqnmxi]{Debate Reward}
If the PCs solve this encounter via debate, the two are impressed. Kespern thanks them by giving the party a scroll of energy aegis, while Cilamali does so with a gift two greater healing potions.

Reward: If the PCs stop the debate before the two fight, grant them 40 XP. If they do so without resorting to magic or violence themselves via Debating the Spellcasters, increase this reward to 80 XP.

Event 4: Uninvited Viewing.text:
Event 4. Uninvited Viewing

The PCs are approached by a nervous guard named Kalden Dromit (desperate male human guard 8), who hurriedly explains that an important guest, a provocative artist from Ustalav named Pelthia (enthusiastic nonbinary elf artist 10), has gone somewhere they shouldn't—into the Nemteriak Art Gallery. Kalden explains further that Aun Nemteriak (talented female human nephilim painter 14), the owner of the gallery, is in Absalom as part of a delegation from Xin-Eurythnia to help orchestrate the linking of the two cities via the Circle of Open Hands portal. Kalden admits that he works for Aun Nemteriak, but his only job was to stand vigil outside the entrance, noting that the gallery itself is well protected by numerous magical defenses while it remains closed. It doesn't take much further to get Kalden to shamefully admit he accepted a payment from Pelthia to look the other way so they could enter the gallery to take advantage of this opportunity to admire some of Aun's collection. Pelthia promised to only spend thirty minutes inside, but now it's been nearly two hours and Kalden fears that either Pelthia has become trapped (or worse), or that they had some sort of nefarious plan to rob the place.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.MOgz1wSKEuKLN0Km]{Nemteriak Art Gallery}

Kalden admits he made a mistake, claiming that the bribe (a shimmering gemstone that is in fact an eye of apprehension ) was too good to turn down and that he knew Pelthia by reputation and trusted them, and now he fears the worst. He knows the PCs and sought them out, hoping they can discretely help by entering the Art Gallery, finding Pelthia, and escorting them back out—all without making a scene so that Kalden can keep his job. Kalden is normally a trustworthy man, and this momentary lapse of judgment is not an indication of a darker motive, as a PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,action:sense-motive|name:Sense Motive] check to Sense Motive can ascertain.

If the PCs don't help, the city guard soon becomes involved and a bit of damage is done to the Art Gallery in the process of rescuing Pelthia; Kalden is eventually fired as a result. If the PCs suggest contacting Aun and having him return, Kalden goes pale at the thought of facing his boss but points out that Aun is an important part of the far side of the Unveiling Ritual; distracting him could threaten the ceremony itself. In the end, contacting Aun results in him alerting the city guard from Absalom via a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.R9xqCBblkS5KE4y7]{Sending} spell, with an identical end result detailed above.

If the PCs agree to aid him, Kalden breathes a sigh of relief and escorts the PC to the Nemteriak Art Gallery nearby. He unlocks the front door with his key, and asks the PCs to try to do their best to not do too much damage in there, but the important thing is to find Pelthia and get her back out. He gives the PCs a quick rundown of the art gallery's floor plan, and informs them that Pelthia seemed particularly keen on visiting a display of Ustalavic paintings in the gallery's east wing.

The Nemteriak Art Gallery is artfully lit by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.mRz8Jmk4Q06SsZpC]{Everlight Crystals} perfectly placed by each individual art piece. The paintings, sculptures, and other works of art on display are placed in framed alcoves or atop equally artful pedestals or display cases. Glittering chandeliers hang from the ceiling, glimmering with several more everlight crystals that keep the gallery well lit.

This rescue mission plays out using the Infiltration rules ( GM Core 196); the PCs don't have time to pursue any of the typical preparation activities, but Kalden's advice grants them 1 Edge Point for use on overcoming any of the obstacles they'll face in the gallery as they seek out Pelthia.

Opportunity.name: Opportunity
Opportunity.text:
Opportunity

A PC can choose to pursue the following opportunity.

Support Your Allies Opportunity

Requirements The party currently has no Edge Points

While the others work on overcoming the current obstacle, you instead keep an eye out for unexpected opportunities to take advantage of to aid the others. Attempt a @Check[perception|dc:32] check.

Critical Success The party gains 2 Edge Points.

Success The party gains 1 Edge Point.

Critical Failure The party accrues 1 Awareness Point.

Awareness Points.name: Awareness Points
Awareness Points.text:
Awareness Points

As the PCs race to rescue Pelthia, word slowly spreads of trouble in the Nemteriak Art Gallery. Once the PCs accrue 20 Awareness Points, several city guards accompanied by a few wizards enter the art gallery and help to rescue Pelthia, ending the infiltration. One of the PCs must attempt to overcome the following complication as well.

Explain Yourselves! Complication

Trigger The PCs accrue 20 Awareness Points.

Overcome @Check[legal-lore|dc:30] ( to cite precedents that allow citizens to break into buildings to provide aid), @Check[diplomacy|dc:32] (to calmly justify what you were up to in the Art Gallery), or @Check[deception|dc:35] (to trick the authorities into thinking you had permission from the owner)

You attempt to explain why the party was in the art gallery, cover up Kalden's mistake, and/or provide a reason why you didn't just contact the authorities.

Success The authorities let you off with a warning.

Failure The authorities take you into custody, and you spend the next few hours there. The party misses the chance to take part in the final repetition of @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01event1enjoyi00]{Event 1} just before @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris.JournalEntryPage.01event5devast00]{Event 5}, but the authorities ultimately let the PCs go—they return to Temple Plaza just in time for the final event to begin.

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.text:
Getting Started

The adventure begins a few days before the grand reveal of the Circle of Open Hands, with the PCs having just arrived in Xin-Eurythnia to attend the activation of the grand portal. The PCs have some time to explore the recently renamed city and to enjoy their privileges as honored guests. Give the players time to introduce their characters if you're starting with fresh new PCs, time to pursue some last-minute shopping, or simply let them get to know the city layout.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.8qeh8s2PAVOnGzhI]{Xin-Eurythnia} @UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.9QgNNV7ShgSQvV9W]{Xin-Eurythnia Indoors}

The Revenge of the Runelords Player's Guide not only helps to guide the creation of new PCs for this campaign but also gives options and suggestions for PCs to explore in Xin-Eurythnia, including some fun downtime activities. Give the players a short bit of time to pursue what activities they wish. One thing to note, though—when this adventure begins, none of the PCs should yet have their mythic destinies. Players can know full well which one they intend to take for their characters, but until the following event takes place, the mythic destinies awaiting the PCs have yet to begin.

Dreams of Destiny.name: Dreams of Destiny
Dreams of Destiny.text:
Dreams of Destiny

After settling down for the night, the PCs find themselves sharing a dream of the past. Even if the PC does not normally sleep or dream, the power of the person summoning them into the Dreamlands is strong enough to pull their sleeping mind in with the rest of the party as they rest.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.GicBaCSfkBHIAYAb]{Dreams of Destiny}

When the PCs wake, they do so somewhere else, somewhere familiar: the location where they initially gathered to go on their first adventure. This could be the tavern in which they first met, the marketplace from their shared hometown, or even at the entrance of the first dungeon they explored. When you describe this familiar location, note also how the details seem strangely off. Any visible clocks have hands pointing at illegible numbers. Water in rivers seems to flow too slowly or even backwards. Music or lighting wells up from unseen sources to lend an air of comfort or solemnity. Other people in the background might appear to be going about their daily business, but faces are indistinct and hard to discern, and spoken words sound more like background noise in a quiet crowd than they do intelligible speech. The PCs appear to be fully dressed and equipped for adventuring in the same gear they had on the day of their first adventure, but on closer inspection a PC can confirm they're equipped in the same gear they had at hand the previous day. Any PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[occultism|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or a @Check[perception|dc:22|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge realizes that they're in a dream—a critical success confirms they're in a shared dream, likely one sent by a powerful entity.

Once the PCs have collected themselves, a disembodied, lilting voice speaks to them. Initially, this voice sounds like that of someone they trust from their childhood such as that of a parent, sibling, or friend, or perhaps even of the voice of a patron or deity. Each PC hears a different voice speaking in their native tongue.

“Well met, travelers... or should I say, great heroes of Golarion? That's who I'm looking for, but I must be sure. We've gathered here on the eve of your first adventure, but you would know more of your glories than I. Share them with me, if you would care to indulge me?”

At this moment, the PCs each recall an emotionally powerful, defining moment in their lives that led them to become who they are today—their mythic calling. Give each player a moment to recount the event in which they gained their mythic calling, and to explain why they chose the specific calling they did. As they answer, the history they recall unravels around them in the dreamscape through living visions and phantasmal imagery. During all of this, each PC gets the feeling that the source of the mysterious voice is listening, watching, and approving. When they finish, the voice speaks again, and now the faint image of a human woman shimmers at the edge of each PC's peripheral vision, yet any attempt to look directly at her causes the image to vanish.

“It seems fate has chosen well, for you are worthy to craft Golarion's future. Tell me, heroes, what destiny do you see before you? What future will you create for our world?”

The PCs now choose their mythic destiny. As suggested in the Revenge of the Runelords Player's Guide , each player has likely already selected their character's destiny, but it's during this shared dream that those destinies become realities for each PC. Have each player announce their choice of mythic destiny, and after each declaration, prompt the PC with the following lines of inspiration before asking each player to describe their new dream form in detail.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.dpkGYM2QObR5QbBH]{Apocalypse Rider}: The PC finds themself atop a powerful mount with a fiendish countenance, looking out over a legion of their enemies facing their doom.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.HPav9ntIOl5WMmFY]{Archfiend}: The PC takes on a fiendish visage as they survey their personal realm.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.zDmc6JlvdVzHEtcE]{Ascended Celestial}: The PC emanates holy light, their appearance growing more celestial and holy.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.Af7vcTToxetHThj4]{Avenging Runelord}: The PC is joined by a ghostly image of the runelord who has attached to them.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.DgYC8yxISZ6Dfmky]{Beast Lord}: The PC is briefly superimposed with an image of their companion as if they were one combined being, then their companion appears beside them for the rest of the dream.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.4vR3Z6B60cjpQ7xW]{Broken Chain}: The PC bears a banner that ripples between the different flags of nations—some that currently exist, some that will be formed in the future—that might find hope in their power and strength.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.ZI7WQ1en8s5VG6fk]{Eternal Legend}: The PC is dressed in fine garb and grows more akin to their true idealized self.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.JbE823xBNt12IAD5]{Heroic Scion}: The PC shifts in appearance so that they take on the form of their previous heroic life.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.102gdaYHnMFoDRL1]{Godling}: The PC shines with divine radiance as they transform into the figure they're destined to be worshipped as.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.Y1hwTaDIIBKtSCZe]{Prophesied Monarch}: The PC wears a crown with regal clothing or armor, and carries a symbol of power such as an elaborate scepter or a bejeweled orb.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.yrlwMnjLgKaWtq74]{Timewracked}: The PC shimmers and wavers as other versions of themselves, each in different stages of health or armed with different weapons or gear, seem to manifest and swap places as multiple timelines overlap.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.GtohZQvFVZaIQD0S]{Warshard Warrior}: The PC's favored weapon glows and shimmers with magical power, perhaps growing, becoming more bejeweled, or the like.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.feats-srd.Item.QRnlCBpFkzqP1rBJ]{Wildspell}: The PC glows with power from within, raw magic occasionally lighting up their veins or glowing from their eyes in flashing colors.

Give the players time to update their character sheets with their mythic destinies if they didn't take care of this in advance during character creation. If the PC's mythic destiny involves a companion, that companion is now at their side in the dream and able to aid them in the upcoming encounter.

The Eighth Runelord.name: The Eighth Runelord
The Eighth Runelord.text:
The Eighth Runelord

When the PCs have completed their final destiny choice, the owner of the mysterious voice manifests fully before them. This mysterious woman is Liralarue (serene female human dream phantom wizard 20), a wizard from the ancient days of Thassilon who focused her studies on divination magic rather than one of the traditionally accepted subjects of her time. Liralarue was obsessed with creating her own runewell to escape Earthfall and join the ranks of the runelords as their eighth member but succeeded at neither task. Having failed to ascend to her desired height of power before calamity struck, Liralarue escaped into the Dreamlands, where she's dwelt for thousands of years as a dream phantom. These centuries have brought her a sense of peace and humility that life never did, and she exists between life and death, bearing an immortality she no longer craves. Her divination powers have become a form of foresight into all possible futures, and while she's seen the destruction Xanderghul's plans could wreak in most futures, she's also seen heroes rise against him. Unfortunately, the details of these visions elude her, and her existence in dreams prevents her from enacting an actual effect on the waking world. Her visions have thus led her to contact the PCs themselves through the veil of dreams to see if they can take up the task of preventing the budding apocalypse set into motion by the runelord of pride.

Liralarue is an incredibly obscure persona, one whose legacy has remained hidden almost completely from the modern world until recently, when events in and near the town of Sandpoint brought her back toward prominence. Nonetheless, a PC must succeed at a @Check[arcana|dc:32|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[society|dc:35|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] to Recall Knowledge to identify her (although if the PCs have played through Seven Dooms for Sandpoint, they'll likely be able to identify her automatically). Regardless, she introduces herself soon enough.

“Now that your destiny is upon you, let me speak openly. I am Liralarue, the runelord who never was. I had dreams of becoming an eighth ruler of Thassilon, as powerful and feared as those whose names you still know today. Alas, the dreams I held were not to be. Earthfall came, and I fled into the Dreamlands, where I've remained since. I've found peace in lifetime after lifetime wandering the dreams of others. I'm now untangled from my own fate; my dreams were not to come true, yet now in truth I am a dream.

“And in those dreams, I see futures. All futures. An endless churn of waves on the tide. I don't know which futures are destined for reality, only that there exist paths toward them all. And you, whose destinies are now upon you? I've seen you in so many of those paths. Some lead to triumph. Most lead to despair and ruin. This is why I've called your dreams to me. You must achieve your destiny to prevent the worst of many futures, and I am here to...”

Before Liralarue can continue, a piercing shriek ripples down from above. A falling star trailing three tails—one red, one midnight black, and one iridescent—plummets into the dream. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[occultism|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[religion|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes this as a vision of the Trinity Star. As it strikes the land, the scenery around the PCs explodes, and Liralarue's phantasmal form rips apart with a scream. Each PC endures an apocalyptic scene of their own destiny reaching dire and detestable dooms, all melting together into a horrific collage of nightmares as a gray-cloaked figure looms above them. As it speaks in a voice of thunder, the PCs taste ashes in their mouths.

“You can prevent nothing. Your destinies are hollow. Idle fancies as you await the end of all things. Perish here and know your journey is done before it even begins.”

This cloaked figure is the Ashen Man (malicious male ancient one 23), the entity who guided the Trinity Star to Golarion. The Ashen Man has grown weary of Golarion's heroes thwarting apocalypses and is determined to put a stop to Liralarue's attempts to intervene with the ending he so craves. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[occultism|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[religion|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] to Recall Knowledge identifies the Ashen Man as the figurehead for many apocalyptic cults, but the PCs have little time to act on this knowledge, for his destruction of Liralarue's dreamscape has plunged them all into an even greater vision of cataclysmic doom.

Apocalyptic Visions.name: Apocalyptic Visions
Apocalyptic Visions.text:
Apocalyptic Visions

While this dreamscape's collapse has no grander impact on the waking world or the Dreamlands, it can have dreadful consequences on the PCs if they cannot navigate their way through their crumbling memories and nightmarish terrors back to the waking world.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.tQYBROfWJPptHyrn]{Apocalyptic Visions}

This encounter is a mythic deed and uses the Chase subsystem ( GM Core 192), where the PCs must attempt skill checks to endure the horrible visions of their legacies being destroyed long enough for them to awaken. As with all chases in which the PCs are attempting to beat the clock, they are not pursued or pursuing a foe. Instead, they must get through all six of the following obstacles before six rounds pass.

Although this chase takes place in a dreamscape, limited resources function as they do in the waking world. More astoundingly, any consumables a PC uses during this chase remain consumed upon waking.

During this chase, as the Ashen Man preys upon PC memories, describe how they're being warped into nightmarish terrors. With each obstacle, incorporate pieces of the PCs' pasts into the obstacles. They might witness NPCs they saved from peril cry out in anguish as they're slain, powerful monsters or foes they defeated live on to ravage regions, or endure the destruction of locations of safety and nostalgia. If you don't know these details, ask the PCs what memories they glimpse in the horror of the dreamscape, and impress upon them the conviction that if they can't wake up soon, these memories will replace the past to become today's reality.

Memories in Flames Obstacle

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[athletics|dc:32] to fight against the fires long enough for friends and relatives to escape, @Check[nature|dc:35] to assess the likely direction the flames will take and to guide refugees to safety rather than into the fire, @Check[crafting|dc:40] to build firebreaks impossibly quickly.

Waves of iridescent flames wash over the landscape, destroying the PCs' ancestral homes in a raging inferno of rainbow fire that eats away at their memories of childhood.

Undead Hordes Obstacle

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[religion|dc:32] to use prayer to turn back the advancing horde, @Check[stealth|dc:35] to hide from the undead and escape unnoticed, @Check[deception|dc:40] to hide your own life and trick the undead into ignoring you as one of them.

A massive wave of undead rushes out from the iridescent flames, clawing at anyone they can.

Blood Rain Obstacle

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[crafting|dc:32] to quickly jury-rig rafts or buoys or other methods to stay afloat, @Check[athletics|dc:35] to swim through the floodwaters, @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save to hold your breath for what seems like hours as you're swept along.

A rain of blood pours from the sky, evoking recent memories of the Godsrain, yet where this blood falls, it gathers quickly into a flood that washes away great swaths of land, carrying away entire cities.

The World Opens Obstacle

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[acrobatics|dc:32] to scramble atop crumbling roofs and landscapes to avoid plummeting into rifts, @Check[diplomacy|dc:35] to guide crowds of survivors to the last few remaining safe places, @Check[athletics|dc:40] to hold a rift closed with your hands long enough for others to flee the area.

As rivers of blood cut rifts into the world, tremors rip through the land. Rifts yawn open, mountains crumble, and the oceans begin to drain as the planet begins to crumble.

Devoid of Life Obstacle

Chase Points 2

Overcome @Check[fortitude|dc:32] to resist the pull of death, DC 35 any lore to make a record of your world's history so that whoever comes next might learn from your mistakes and triumphs, @Check[medicine|dc:40] to protect the lives of those close to you from this sudden void.

The world is suddenly stripped of all life, water receding into cracked earth as plants wither and the sun explodes into scorching heat before freezing cold and eternal night consume what's left. Only a very few survive.

Endless Fall Obstacle

Chase Points 3

Overcome @Check[performance|dc:32] to laugh in the face of the end with a song or other performance in the face of certain doom, @Check[fortitude|dc:35] to resist shattering along with the rest of reality, @Check[thievery|dc:40] to disable the unraveling of reality by stealing away a shard of entropy.

The world shatters into an endless void, pieces of the dream flying through the air as darkness threatens to swallow up all memories and life.

Awakening: If the PCs manage to overcome all six obstacles before they run out of time at the end of the sixth round of the chase, they wake up in their rooms with no injuries. While memories of this horrific dream remain fresh and the discovery that they all shared the same dream might be unsettling, they've come out the other side with mythic destinies, having endured their first encounter with the Ashen Man. If a PC chose a mythic destiny that includes a companion or mount, they quickly see the ramifications of this choice. If the companion involved in the PC's destiny is entirely new, they appear in the PC's room at the inn unless they're too big; in this case, they're patiently waiting outside the inn and, perhaps unintentionally, frightening off passersby with their presence.

If the PCs fail to overcome all six obstacles, they still awaken from the dream with their mythic destinies, yet they cannot shake the conviction that the Ashen Man's warning is more of a promise than a prediction. They do not regain any Mythic Points for this mythic deed. Additionally, each PC becomes plagued by night terrors; the next time they sleep, each PC must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:32] save to avoid awakening @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued} (or drained 2 and fatigued on a critical failure).

Rewards: If the PCs overcome all six obstacles and awaken safely, each PC restores 3 Mythic Points. For each obstacle the PCs overcome, they earn 20 XP, for a maximum of 120 XP if they overcome all six. Alternatively, if your PCs are lower level and you're using the Swift Leveling in a Dream option, the PCs should level up to 12th level at this point, resetting their current XP to 0.

Whispers of Danger.name: Whispers of Danger
Whispers of Danger.text:
Whispers of Danger

Soon after awakening from their vision, the PCs learn they've been invited to Midnight's Gallery, @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21904noctic]{Nocticula's} cathedral in the main square of the city, where the Circle of Open Hands portal is being constructed. The sender of the invitation is the temple's leader, Ayavah, who may already be known to some of the PCs.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.re6oP2DNCoCc20Yy]{Midnight's Gallery}

Located in the northern reach of the city, Midnight's Gallery is an impressive building adorned with unusual sculptures and great stained-glass windows. The windows depict imagery of the night sky and a woman wreathed in stars reaching out to tiny humanoid figures. The sculptures vary in shape and size, but the most prominent are of succubi. The building's modern appearance is a far cry from its former one, for until Queen Sorshen's return and Nocticula's ascension to divinity, this building was known as the House of Divine Consumption—a temple devoted to no god, but to the very ideals of greed.

Ayavah welcomes the PCs' arrival with a smile and open arms, particularly if some of them are already known to her. To others, she introduces herself. “I am Ayavah. Welcome to Xin-Eurythnia, and thank you for accepting my invitation!”

Ayavah has a strong sense of love and duty for the people of the city, especially those who find shelter in Nocticula's embrace. Recently, Ayavah's become concerned by rumors of a cult planning to sabotage the unveiling ceremony. Unfortunately, all Ayavah knows about these rumors is that this cult calls themselves the Risen of the Trinity Star, suggesting that they have something to do with the mysterious falling star that many saw fall over the Kodar Mountains over a year ago, yet of which no trace was found. As one of Xin-Eurythnia's civic leaders, she hopes to learn more about this threat before she escalates the issue to Queen Sorshen's attention, and her existing relationship with one or more of the PCs (or merely their fame) made contacting them to investigate the veracity of these rumors the best choice at the time.

These rumors, Ayavah explains, suggest that the Risen of the Trinity Star have been recently active in or near an old dawnsilver workshop in the Artisan District; she suggests the PCs investigate the workshop first, but there might be other rumors she's missed if the party wishes to take some time Gathering Information about the cult.

Xin-Eurythnia.name: Xin-Eurythnia
Xin-Eurythnia.text:
Xin-Eurythnia

Before one learns of the current state of the city of Xin-Eurythnia, a brief history lesson on the settlement is needed. Founded in the year –6475 ar to serve as the capital city for the nation of Shalast, at the time ruled by Runelord Kaladurnae, Xin-Shalast was one of the first of Thassilon's great cities to begin construction, but the last to be completed. Runelord Kaladurnae chose the site of his capital city for its remoteness, reasoning that building at an elevation of just above 15,000 and in the shadow of the Kodars' (and Avistan's) tallest mountain would give the city unparalleled defense against his enemies. Runelord Kaladurnae abandoned the strange fortress of Kaer Maga in favor of this new location as his nation's capital, and while by –6470 ar he'd put Kaer Maga to use as a vast prison, his hopes for Xin-Shalast faced hardship after hardship. By the time of his death in –6448 ar, the only structure of lasting significance in the struggling settlement was the House of Divine Consumption, a secular “temple” established by Kaladurnae in hopes of fostering his own cult of personality. Kaladurnae's rule was followed by that of Runelord Fethryr, and while she ruled over four times as long as her predecessor, Xin-Shalast grew slowly under her, in large part due to her greed preventing the spending of funds required to expand much from what Kaladurnae started. Her greatest addition to the city was the towering arena known as the Heptaric Locus. Intended to serve as the nation's heart, countless mass battles and bloodsports were performed within for Fethryr's (and those who followed her rule) entertainment.

Even though the runelords successfully conspired to assassinate King Xin and took full control of Thassilon during the height of Runelord Fethryr's rule, it wasn't until the third runelord of greed, Runelord Gimmel, took her place that Xin-Shalast finally began to grow. Utilizing magically compelled giants under the command of a legion of rune giants, the sprawl of Xin-Shalast grew swiftly. Gimmel's risky but successful conjuration of the Oliphaunt in –6301 ar to lay waste to an invading Azlanti army would secure his legend and power for over a century, during which he oversaw the vast expansion of Xin-Shalast into a proper city. By –6192, the city reached its apex, but Runelord Gimmel didn't live much longer to enjoy this success. Under the rule of the next four runelords of greed, the opulence and splendor of Xin-Shalast grew, but its sprawl did not. It wasn't until the final runelord of greed, Runelord Karzoug, took control of Shalast that the city expanded again—this time upward along the treacherous slopes of Mhar-Massif in the new Rising District. Karzoug's construction of the Spires of Xin-Shalast and his personal palace, the Pinnacle of Avarice, near the dormant volcano's peak would be eclipsed only by his most audacious addition to the city skyline—an immense bust of his own visage carved into the mountain itself, so that Karzoug's imperious gaze could look down over the city for the eons to come.

As it happened, those “eons to come” were just over four and a half centuries, for when Earthfall struck, Xin-Shalast suffered as did every city in Thassilon. Earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and flows of lava devastated the city, reducing its footprint to a twisted, hook-shaped valley, and over the thousands of years to follow, the city slowly fell into ruin. Ancient Thassilonian magic helped to preserve much of the architecture from the depredations of time, but those many centuries of occupation by monsters took its toll. By the time the Age of Lost Omens began, Xin-Shalast was largely believed to be a myth—a place thought of by those few who knew the name as a fanciful paradise city located on some far-distant shore. It wasn't until Karzoug's rise in 4707 that Xin-Shalast was “re-discovered,” and with the defeat of Runelord Alaznist's attempt to reshape history in 4718, the monster-haunted ruins of Xin-Shalast finally began their rebirth as Queen Sorshen, having abandoned her title of runelord after returning to Golarion, chose it as her new capital city.

Queen Sorshen has transformed the ruins of Xin-Shalast. While certain sections of the city remain dangerous, particularly those long buried underground by ancient lava flows, the surface sprawl of the city is largely now a safe harbor for all who seek shelter within. Yet her hope of turning the city into a place of welcome for all who seek to study magic or explore innovation has faltered against the same complications that vexed those who originally built the city—its isolation and elevation. While she's managed to largely combat the issues caused by elevation by creating dozens of “solace spires” to combat the cold and thin air, the city's isolation has remained a struggle. Land routes must navigate treacherous high-altitude passes, and the construction of safer roads continues to take time and resources, while flight must contend with treacherous winds and sudden storms that plague the Kodars. Queen Sorshen's solution, to craft the first of several portals to connect her capital city with allied cities throughout the world, is nearing completion, and to celebrate this step into the modern world, the city known for thousands of years as Xin-Shalast will now be known as Xin-Eurythnia, in honor of her own long-lost capital city, where modern-day Korvosa now stands.

Today, Xin-Eurythnia's primary religion is worship of @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21904noctic]{Nocticula}, the Redeemer Queen, and her influence can be seen in the large number of transplants from southern Varisia who have found safe haven here. Outside of these migrants, most of the population is a mixture of Thassilonians who fled the tyranny of Runelord Belimarius after being restored to the modern timeline, artists and creators from nations beyond Varisia who fled persecution in their homeland, and a small but notable number of giants, lamias, and other creatures who continued to dwell in the ruined city after Karzoug's defeat. The majority of these “monsters” keep to themselves on the fringes of the city or in its significant underground reaches and do not seek to prey upon the new citizens who dwell above—a delicate diplomatic balance that's one of Queen Sorshen's many triumphs during her tenure as city ruler, especially considering a not insignificant number of these creatures continue their violent tendencies and periodically prey upon those who live on the streets above.

The vast majority of the buildings in Xin-Eurythnia are of stone and built to last—most still enjoy the protection of ancient preservative magic, but these wards do nothing against violent destruction (be it the result of directed demolition or natural disaster). Many of the buildings in the southern portion of the city, particularly those along the east side, were buried or partially destroyed by an ancient lava flow, while elsewhere, cracked facades and roofs damaged during Earthfall present what appears to be an unstable structure, when in fact these buildings are quite solid. The scale of most of the city's buildings is immense—built by the hands of giants, there are very few buildings smaller than a hundred feet to a side, while doors tend to be oversized and rooflines high. The vast majority of the buildings remain abandoned—two thirds of the population dwell in the city's northern half, giving Xin-Eurythnia an almost ghost-town like feeling at times.

While certain areas of Xin-Eurythnia feature in this chapter, the PCs aren't going to be spending a lot of time here, and while there are places for them to shop, relax, and role-play in between their adventures during Chapter 1 beyond these featured locations, you should resist the urge to spend too much time in the city. When the time comes to abandon Xin-Eurythnia during @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight]{Chapter 2}, staying behind to defend a doomed city should not be a distraction!

Ancient ruined city on the cusp of a modern revival.

Government Queen (overlord)

Population 12,500 (60% humans, 8% dwarves, 6% dromaars, 5% nephilim, 5% orcs, 4% aiuvarins, 3% elves, 2% giants, 1% lamias, 6% other ancestries)

Languages Common, Dwarven, Jotun, Orcish, Shoanti, Thassilonian, Varisian

Religions @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.swwwP7eVmlNuWTb7]{Gozreh}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.9EKyWmjLUu42evxC]{Nethys}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.jL1qiVOZBKXETtVD]{Nocticula}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.gxwmzxUWBOhdgFSN]{Shelyn}

Ancient Magics Xin-Eurythnia's large population of ancient mages means it offers higher level access to magic items; common alchemical and magic items above 15th level can be purchased here, although often they must be hand-crafted or imported, resulting in a delay of some days at the GM's discretion. In addition, the rare @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21905advent.JournalEntryPage.05thassilonian00]{Thassilonian Treasures} (elixirs of the peaks, Sihedron medallions, and Sihedron rings) can be purchased here as well.

Solace Spires Sorshen erected a dozen of these 80-foot-tall stone spires around the perimeter of Xin-Eurythnia not long after she arrived in the ruined settlement years ago. These magical spires ward the city itself from the cold and altitude of the region. Citizens and visitors alike are constantly protected from the effects of severe and extreme cold and can breathe easily as if they were fully acclimated to the altitude.
